page.title: 06SKINNER'S JOURNAL
page.content: Born in 1772, John Skinner's career as a lawyer lasted only 3 years until he decided to take Holy Orders. After a short curacy at Claverton, in 1800 Skinner's uncle purchased for him the living of Camerton.He looked forward to a tranquil life in a peaceful village where he could be both priest and scholar. Instead he encountered strife and unrest in a coalmining community; he was faced with the evils of drink, poverty, indiscipline and immorality. He felt bound to tell the people of their faults and was hated for it. He was in constant dispute with the Lord of the Manor. He took refuge in his journals and research into local history, filling 98 vols. of manuscript to be remembered as an antiquary and as a much wronged man. His unhappiness became too much to bear and in 1839 he shot himself.
